elements.title: First, this service will ask about the person who died. Details about their life will affect later questions. That is why this service will ask about you, the `applicant(s)`, in a later step.

elements.name: deceasedName
elements.title: What is the name of the person who died?
elements.description:
If {deceasedName} made a `Will`, you should use the exact spelling of their name on their Will.

If {deceasedName} did not make a Will, you should use the exact spelling of their name on their government-issued photo ID.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ1
elements.title: What if the {deceasedName} used more than one spelling or version of their name?
elements.body: This service will ask you for other spellings and versions of {deceasedName}'s name in a later step.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ2
elements.title: What if {deceasedName}'s name is originally in a different language?
elements.body: You will need a version of {deceasedName}'s name that is written using the Roman alphabet. English and French are examples of languages that use the Roman alphabet.

elements.title:

Would you like this service to show you a more familiar name instead?
elements.description: This familiar name is only used to personalize your experience with this service. It will not appear on the actual `Representation Grant`.

elements.name: deceasedNickname
elements.title: What name would you like to see instead of "{deceasedName}"?
elements.description:
You can choose any name you like. For example, "your husband" or "Uncle Jesse" or "Cousin Stavros".

You can always come back to change this name at any time.

elements.name: jiraRepgrant29
elements.title: JIRA ticket REPGRANT-29 - Deceased Nickname Substitution

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeath
elements.title: When did {deceasedName} die?
elements.description: If you are unsure, this date can be found on {deceasedName}'s `Certificate of Death`.

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeathFAQ1
elements.title: How do I get a Certificate of Death?
elements.body:
A `Certificate of Death` comes from the place where {deceasedName} died.

If {deceasedName} died in British Columbia, their Certificate of Death comes from the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. You can get a Certificate of Death directly from Vital Statistics or you can ask a funeral home to get a Certificate of Death for you.

Click here for more information from the Government of British Columbia's website. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of British Columbia but still inside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the province or territory where they died.

Click here for other Vital Statistics Agencies in Canada. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the state or country where they died.

  • write "no fixed address" for the street number and street name
  • Write the city/town, province and country where they lived.
  • Write "n/a" for their postal code.

elements.name: willIntroExplanation
elements.title:
This step in the service will ask if {deceasedName} made a `Will` or any `other testamentary documents`.

The questions in this step will be very technical. Please read the content carefully. This step may be the most complicated one in this service. This service will likely feel easier after this step.

If {deceasedName} made a Will, there will be a lot of questions about the Will. These questions help prove to the Court that {deceasedName}'s Will represents how {deceasedName} wants their belongings managed.

elements.name: willPreviousWillCheckBookmark
elements.title: Previous Will Check

elements.name: willCheck
elements.title: Have you looked for {deceasedName}'s `Will`
elements.description:
This means checking all the places where {deceasedName} kept important documents.

Physical places include their home, safety deposit box, and their lawyer's office.

Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ1
elements.title: Do I have to look for {deceasedName}'s Will all by myself?
elements.body:
The person applying for a `Representation Grant` has to look for {deceasedName}'s `Will`.

If several people are applying together for a `Representation Grant`, you can decide which `applicant` looks where.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ2
elements.title: Do I have to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now?
elements.body:
A "Search of Wills Notice" is a document from the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia that might be able to tell you where to find {deceasedName} `Will` (if they made one).

You will need a "Search of Wills Notice" as part of your `Representation Grant` `application`. You can get a "Search of Wills Notice" on your own at anytime, or you can wait for this service to help you get this document in a later step.

The reason this service helps you get a "Search of Wills Notice" in a later step is because it needs to include all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their `assets`.

If you believe {deceasedName} made a `Will` and you feel you need help finding it now, you may consider getting a "Search of Wills Notice" right now.

If you want to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now, click here to download a blank form. (This link opens in a new tab)

It is up to you whether you want to get a "Search of Wills Notice" on your own, or if you want to wait and have this service help you get one in a later step. Whichever the choice, this service will check that your "Search of Wills Notice" was done correctly for your application.

elements.name: willCheckNoError
elements.title:
You are responsible for making sure if {deceasedName} made a `Will` or not.

Please look in all the places where {deceasedName} kept important documents.

Physical places include their home, safety deposit box, and their lawyer's office.

Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.

If you believe {deceasedName} made a Will and you feel you need help finding it, click on "Do I need to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now?". (This can be found right above)

elements.name: willGrantExistsNoErrorCurrent
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. At this time, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you need to add a new person onto the Representation Grant, please talk to a lawyer. This is not a simple matter.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you have more `assets` to report, stop using this service. Use either form P14 or P15 to tell the court. Forms P14 and P15 can be found here. (This link opens in a new tab)

If the existing Representation Grant is from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, the existing Representation Grant can be resealed. Please refer to the Supreme Court Civil Rules under Rule 25-6 - Application for Resealing for information on resealing the Representation Grant. (This link opens in a new tab)

If the existing Representation Grant is not from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, you will have to apply for an ancillary Representation Grant. The forms to apply for an ancillary grant can be found here. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: willExistsFAQ1Temporary
elements.title: What if I believe {deceasedName} made a Will but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you cannot find {deceasedName}'s `Will`, you can keep looking for it or you can decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will.

If you decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will, Select "No" to this question. If you find {deceasedName}'s Will after you already got your Representation Grant, you can apply for a new Representation Grant using their Will to replace the old one.

If you believe {deceasedName} made a Will and you decide to keep looking for it, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant at this time. For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations.

The Government of British Columbia offers PDF forms that you may find helpful for applications where {deceasedName} made a Will. Click here to go to the forms. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: willExistsFAQ1Future
elements.title: What if I believe {deceasedName} made a Will but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you cannot find {deceasedName}'s `Will`, you can keep looking for it or you can decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will.

If you decide to keep looking for {deceasedName}'s Will, only select "Yes" to this question when you find their Will.

If you decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will, Select "No" to this question.
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will before you finish applying for your Representation Grant, come back to this question and change the answer/selection to "Yes".
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will after you already got your Representation Grant, you can apply for a new Representation Grant using their Will to replace the old one.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations.

The Government of British Columbia offers PDF forms that you may find helpful for applications where {deceasedName} made a Will, including unfinished Wills. Click here to go to the forms. (This link opens in a new tab)

If necessary, this service may ask if {deceasedName} made more than one Will.

elements.description:
[Description]The key question is whether the document records a deliberate or fixed and final expression of intention as to the disposal of the deceased’s property on death. A deliberate or fixed and final intention is not the equivalent of an irrevocable intention, given that a will, by its nature, is revocable until the death of its maker. Rather, the intention must be fixed and final at the material time, which will vary depending on the circumstances.

[Reference: https://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcsc/doc/2019/2019bcsc2040/2019bcsc2040.html?searchUrlHash=AAAAAQAoc2VjdGlvbiA1OCB3aWxscywgZXN0YXRlcyBhbmQgc3VjY2Vzc2lvbgAAAAAB&resultIndex=5]

elements.name: question190
elements.title:
Part 3: LEGAL BASIS
[Using numbered paragraphs, specify any rule or other enactment relied on and provide a brief summary of any other legal bases on which the petitioner(s) intend(s) to rely in support of the orders sought.] Para1 1 Section 58 of WESA empowers the court to give the relief requested. Court order curing deficiencies 58 (1)In this section, "record" includes data that (a)is recorded or stored electronically, (b)can be read by a person, and (c)is capable of reproduction in a visible form. (2)On application, the court may make an order under subsection (3) if the court determines that a record, document or writing or marking on a will or document represents (a)the testamentary intentions of a deceased person, (b)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a will or testamentary disposition of the deceased person, or (c)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a testamentary disposition contained in a document other than a will. (3)Even though the making, revocation, alteration or revival of a will does not comply with this Act, the court may, as the circumstances require, order that a record or document or writing or marking on a will or document be fully effective as though it had been made (a)as the will or part of the will of the deceased person, (b)as a revocation, alteration or revival of a will of the deceased person, or (c)as the testamentary intention of the deceased person. (4)If an alteration to a will makes a word or provision illegible and the court is satisfied that the alteration was not made in accordance with this Act, the court may reinstate the original word or provision if there is evidence to establish what the original word or provision was.

elements.title: Spouse Exists

elements.name: spouseExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} have a `spouse` when they died?
elements.description: You do not need to include a spouse that {deceasedName} has divorced and has not resumed a marriage-like relationship.

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include someone who was married (with a marriage certificate) to {deceasedName} if they had separated, but not yet divorced?
elements.body:
Yes, you must include someone who {deceasedName} had legally married but had not divorced. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse`.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include someone who was in marriage-like relationship (also know as a common-law marriage) with {deceasedName}, but they broke up before {deceasedName} died?
elements.body:
No, you do not need to include {deceasedName}'s marriage-like partner (also known as a common-law partner) if they broke up.

A marriage-like relationship ends immediately after the break up. {deceasedName}'s ex-partner would not be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse` anymore.

However, if you are not sure if {deceasedName} and their partner were broken up when {deceasedName} died, it is safer for you to include this person. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ3
elements.title: Do I include someone who was in an on-again, off-again marriage-like relationship with {deceasedName}?
elements.body:
If {deceasedName} lived together with a marriage-like partner (also know as a common-law partner) for at least 2 years, this person would be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse`.

A marriage-like (common law) relationship ends immediately after the break up. However, under the law in British Columbia, this person could still be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse if they broke up and got back together again within a year.

If you are not sure if {deceasedName} and this person had gotten back together before {deceasedName} died, it is safer for you to include this person. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(8)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
templateElements.body:
Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
(8) If a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is a minor, the intended applicant must deliver those documents - (a) as follows: --- (i) if the applicant knows that the minor resides with all of the minor's parents, to those parents; --- (ii) if subparagraph (i) does not apply but the applicant knows that a parent or guardian has responsibility for financial decisions relating to the minor, to that parent or guardian; --- (iii) if neither subparagraph (i) nor subparagraph (ii) applies but the applicant knows of one or more addresses at which the minor resides, to the minor at each of those addresses, and - (b) subject to subrule (9), to the Public Guardian and Trustee.

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(9)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
templateElements.body:
Jack & Tyler (Jul 6 2021) decided to ignore this subrule in favour of service regardless of this situation. The amount of extra programming would likely not be worth the effort considering that a) this subrule doesn't take away that much work from an applicant and b) unnecessary service to minors and their guardians is not likely going to be extra burden.

Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
(9) An intended applicant need not deliver documents under subrule (8) (b) to the Public Guardian and Trustee if - (a) the intended applicant is an executor or alternate executor of the deceased's estate, - (b) the minor is not a spouse or child of the deceased, and - (c) the deceased's will: --- (i) creates a trust for the interest of the minor in the estate, and --- (ii) appoints a trustee for that trust.

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(13)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (13) - Notice to Public Guardian and Trustee
templateElements.body:
Rule 25-2 (13) - Notice to Public Guardian and Trustee

(13) At the time that a notice is delivered to the Public Guardian and Trustee under subrule (8) or (11), the intended applicant must also deliver to the Public Guardian and Trustee a notice, in writing, setting out
- (a) the name of every other person to whom notice is required to be delivered under subrule (8) or (11), and
- (b) the most recent of each of the following that is known to the intended applicant about each of those persons:
--- (i) the person's residential address, inside or outside British Columbia;
--- (ii) the person's postal address, inside or outside British Columbia;
--- (iii) the person's e-mail address;
--- (iv) the person's fax number.

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(10&11)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (10) and (11)
templateElements.body:
If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a mentally incompetent person (10) Subrule (11) applies if - (a) there has been appointed for a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) --- (i) a committee appointed under the Patients Property Act, or --- (ii) the equivalent of a committee appointed by a court outside British Columbia, or - (b) a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is or may be mentally incompetent and paragraph (a) of this subrule does not apply to the person.

How notice may be delivered to a mentally incompetent person (11) If subrule (10) applies to a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1), the intended applicant must deliver the documents to the person as follows: - (a) if subrule (10) (a) (i) applies, by delivering the documents to --- (i) the committee referred to in that subparagraph, and --- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee; - (b) if subrule (10) (a) (ii) applies, by delivering the documents to --- (i) the equivalent person referred to in that subparagraph, and --- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee; - (c) if subrule (10) (b) applies, by delivering the documents to the Public Guardian and Trustee in addition to delivering those documents to the person.

elements.name: spouseCompletedFAQ1
elements.title: How can someone have more than 1 spouse?
elements.body:
Someone can have more than 1 `spouse` depending on the laws where they live.

Under B.C. law, if a person is legally married and they separate from their spouse but do not get a divorce, the person they separated from is still considered their spouse. If that same person then starts a new marriage-like relationship with a new partner, this new partner could be considered a spouse.

In this situation, the person could have 2 spouses because they didn't divorce their first spouse.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: childExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} have any children when they died?

elements.name: childExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s legally adopted children?
elements.body:
Yes, you must include {deceasedName}'s legally adopted children. All of {deceasedName}'s biological and legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {deceasedName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this person was legally adopted by {deceasedName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s step-children?
elements.body:
No, you do not need to include {deceasedName}'s step-children because {deceasedName} did not legally adopt them. Only {deceasedName}'s biological or legally adopted children need to know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {deceasedName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this person was legally adopted by {deceasedName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childExistsFAQ3
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s children (biological or legally adopted) that were legally adopted by someone else?
elements.body:
The answer depends if {deceasedName} was alive when someone else legally adopted their children, and, if {deceasedName} gave up their parenting rights or not.

If {deceasedName} was alive at the time someone else legally adopted {deceasedName}'s children, and {deceasedName} gave up their parenting rights, {deceasedName}'s former children DO NOT need to be included.

If {deceasedName} had already died when {deceasedName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, these children DO need to be included.

If {deceasedName} was alive when {deceasedName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, but {deceasedName} did not give up their parenting rights, these children DO need to be included.

This last situation may happen if the children's other parent(s) gave up their parenting rights but {deceasedName} still kept their parenting rights.

If you are not sure if someone who has been adopted is still considered {deceasedName}'s child or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court considers this person {deceasedName}'s child.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a `Representation Grant`, if they are not {deceasedName}'s child anymore, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s children, if they were adopted, from the Adoption Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: childExistsFAQ4
elements.title: Do I need to include {deceasedName}'s children-in-law?
elements.body: No, you do not need to include {deceasedName}'s children-in-law (the `spouses` of {deceasedName}'s biological or legally adopted children).

No, you do not need to include {panel.childName}'s step-children because {panel.childName} did not legally adopt them. Only {panel.childName}'s biological or legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {panel.childName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this personal was legally adopted by {panel.childName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {panel.childName}'s `estate`.

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ3
templateElements.title: Do I include {panel.childName}'s children (biological or legally adopted) that were legally adopted by someone else?
templateElements.body:
The answer depends if {panel.childName} was alive when someone else legally adopted their children, and, if {panel.childName} gave up their parenting rights or not.

If {panel.childName} was alive at the time someone else legally adopted {panel.childName}'s children, and {panel.childName} gave up their parenting rights, {panel.childName}'s former children DO NOT need to be included.

If {panel.childName} had already died when {panel.childName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, these children DO need to be included.

If {panel.childName} was alive when {panel.childName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, but {panel.childName} did not give up their parenting rights, these children DO need to be included.

This last situation may happen if the children's other parent(s) gave up their parenting rights but {panel.childName} still kept their parenting rights.

If you are not sure if someone who has been adopted is still considered {panel.childName}'s child or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court considers this person {panel.childName}'s child.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a `Representation Grant`, if they are not {panel.childName}'s child anymore, they don't automatically get part of {panel.childName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {panel.childName}'s children, if they were adopt, from the Adoption Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ4
templateElements.title: Do I need to include {panel.childName}'s children-in-law?
templateElements.body: No, you do not need to include {panel.childName}'s children-in-law (the `spouses` of {panel.childName}'s biological or legally adopted children).

templateElements.title: Was {panel.creditorPersonNomineeName} formally appointed to help {panel.creditorPersonName} manage their money and legal decisions?
templateElements.description:
These are the ways someone can be formally appointed.
  • {panel.creditorPersonName} could have signed a document that gave someone else the power of attorney using the Power of Attorney Act,
  • {panel.creditorPersonName} could have signed a document that appointed someone as a representative using the Representation Agreement Act, or
  • a person can be appointed by the Court using the Patients Property Act,
  • a person could have been appointed either the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development or by the Court using the Indian Act

templateElements.name: applicantSpouseListLogic2
templateElements.title: Notes about 130 and 131 from Google Sheets - Copied Nov 4 2021
templateElements.body:
If Applicant has support of spouse, give them 130a. If there is a more than 1 spouse, if anyone of these spouses nominates the child, that is enough to get them 130a even if some other spouses don't support the child.

If Child does not have a spouse's support, but they reaches majority of support of all the living children, give them 130b

If Applicant (non-spouse, non-child) does not have the support of the spouse, but reaches majority of support of all the living children, give them 130c

If Child does not have a spouse's support nor does not reach majority of support of all living children, give them 130d

We will skip 130e and 130f for now until we take in information for other intestate successors.

If Applicant (non-spouse, non-child) does not have a spouse's support nor any support of any living child, give them 130g

-----

WESA 130 (b) a child of the deceased person having the consent of a majority of the children of the deceased person;

what if multiple child applicants on same applicant; and they support each other? probably should be fine.

Do we need consent from a personal rep? No. Only living children have a "vote".

What if the personal rep is a person rep for more than 1 person? Does their vote count as more than 1? No votes for personal reps. Only living children. So if the living child is also a personal rep for 2 other children of the deceased, they only get 1 vote, not 3.

elements.title: Notes and Copywriting from Google Sheets - Nov 4 2021
elements.body:
Coordinating efforts between multiple applicants

When there are multiple people applying to be the deceased's personal representative, the group will need to decide whether to do some of the steps together or separately.

Before you can file your documents at the court, all applicants need to swear/affirm their affidavits. Each affidavit costs around $40 to swear. If applicants can come together to swear their affidavits together, they may be able to save some of the costs.

(Note to dev: Only show if the question Swear Together or Separate is shown. Vertically anchor to the question )

Who should be considered the main applicant?

If a group of applicants decide that it is not possible for everyone to get together to swear their affidavits, we will provide documents for the applicants who will swear separately.

As part of this process, you will need to identify main applicant(s). They are generally the ones who do most of the work. However, this does not mean they have more power over the other appilcants.

If there is more than one main applicant, the main applicants must all swear their affidavits together.

(Note to dev: Only show if the question Main Applicant is shown. Vertically anchor to the question )



Submitting (filing) your application

You will need to submit (file) your application at a court registry. It can be at any Supreme Court registry and usually people file their documents at the Supreme Court registry nearest to where they live or work.

(Note to dev: vertically anchor this paragraph to the question Courthouse Location if possible)

Because your application involves a child under the age of 19 or an adult who is not `mentally competent`, you will need to let the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

if you believe you have tried hard, click here to P41 and sample order

Your affidavit should set out the reasons why personal service is impossible. If it's because you don't know where the respondent is, you should say so. You should also say that you have no means of contacting the respondent, for example, through family or friends. If you can't serve the respondent because they are avoiding service, you should describe how you've tried to serve the respondent and how often you've tried.

If you have no idea at all where the respondent might be, you can ask the judge to allow you to serve the respondent by posting a copy of your Notice of Family Claim in the court registry for a certain period of time, usually no less than 30 days. This is the cheapest means of alternative service, and you really have to show that you've got no idea where the respondent is, no relatives or friends to contact them through, and no idea where the respondent works.

elements.name: notifyEarliestSubmissionDateFAQ2
elements.title: What if I got a Notice of Dispute (Form P29) after I delivered the Form P1?
elements.body:
A Notice of Dispute (Form P29) is the way someone can tell the Court that they don't think you should manage {deceasedName}'s belongings.

You can continue to use this service to complete and file your `application`, but the Court will not give you a Representation Grant until the Notice of Dispute (Form P29) is resolved.

To resolve a Notice of Dispute (Form P29), you can:
  • wait for a year until the Notice of Dispute (Form P29) expires (and is not renewed), or
  • talk things through with the disputant and see if they will withdraw it using the Form P30, or
  • use a Form P31 to apply to the Court to remove the Notice of Dispute (Form P29), if you believe the reason for the dispute is not valid.

Understanding land title certificates
A land title certificate contains a lot of information about a real estate. Here are some of the areas you may find useful for completing the questions. Registered Owner in Fee Simple Shows the owner(s) of the real estate. Taxation Authority
The one receiving property taxes on the real estate
Description of Land
Contains legal description about the real estate.
Charges, Liens and Interests
Lists any mortgages, liens or money owing on the property.

templateElements.title: on title but shouldn't be
templateElements.body:
[Sep 22 2021] - 2017 Spreadsheet Notes
Tyler 1
We would need to go on to say, if you think that the deceased had a joint bank account, put land in joint tenancy for reasons other than for those persons to take sole ownership after they died or was pressured into making a person the beneficiary of their RRSPs or life insurance, then you should contact a lawyer and it is likely best if you do not submit this application on your own."
- turn into an FAQ around joint tenancy area explaining people who shouldn't be on title; doesn't get included anyway; P14 future                                                                     
                          
Tyler 2
If a house that is gifted under a will is also held in joint tenancy then we should be directing a person to contact a lawyer.  I was actually involved in a case where this exact thing happened and the beneficiary under the will (actually the co-beneficiary) successfully argued that his brother (who owned the house in joint tenancy with the mother) held the house as trustee for the estate.  I.e. that the mom put the house in joint tenancy for reasons other than to give the house solely to the one son.    
- same FAQ as Tyler 1

elements.name: willSearchApplicantDiligentSearchConfirmedFAQ1
elements.title: What is a diligent search>
elements.body:
A diligent search is doing your best to check all the places where {deceasedName} usually kept their important documents. This means checking physical places as well electronic places.
  • Physical places include their home, safety deposit box, and their lawyer's office.
  • Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.
If people are working together to apply for a `Representation Grant`, the `applicants` can decide which applicant searches which place.

There is also a document called a Search of Wills Notice. This document can help reveal the location of a will. You don't need to have gotten a Search of Wills Notice to answer "Yes" that you have done a diligent search.

This document is not necessary for your diligent search yes/no but it is eventually necessary. this service will complete it at a later point.
